p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the eighth report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
he committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 15 February 2023, 8 March 2023 and 22 March 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 9 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 18 petitioners—regarding funding for Trove (EN4791)
From 2627 petitioners—regarding the processing time of Parent Visaapplications (EN4798)
From 15 petitioners—regarding the access to Australia of vaccinated people without health insurance (EN4799)
From 748 petitioners—regarding the housing crisis action, regulation of rental increases and vacancy tax (EN4800)
From 26 petitioners—requesting to bring the Australian Rail Track Corporation under direct government control (EN4802)
From 23 petitioners—requesting routine screening for sepsis in Australia (EN4805)
From 117 petitioners—regarding Santos Gas Fracking and protecting the Surat Artesian Basin (EN4806)
From 65 petitioners—requesting to lower the cost of diesel (EN4807)
From 1 petitioner—regarding tick-borne infection testing, treatment and record-keeping in Australia (PN0556)

span.span: 2. The following 22 ministerial responses to petitions were received by the Committee on 22 March 2023:

p.span: From the Attorney-General regarding nationally consistent coercive control laws (EN1948)
From the Minister for Home Affairs to a petition regarding asylum seekers on Manus and Nauru (EN3490)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition regarding Telstra's commitment to the Universal Service Obligation (EN3609)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding citizenship for children born in Australia (EN3934)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting to make the legal age of owning a mobile phone 18 (EN4495)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting the addition of Gymnastics Australia to the National Redress Scheme (EN4498)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding false allegations in court (EN4506)
From the Special Minister of State to a petition regarding voting in Australia (EN4539)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the extradition of Julian Assange (EN4577)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting the regulation of disability parking in Australia (EN4583)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting the introduction of a universal basic income (EN4584)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the situation in Jammu and Kasmir (EN4592)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding the social security partner income test (EN4606)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the conflict in Tigray, northern Ethiopia (EN4617)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the conflict in Tigray, northern Ethiopia (EN4619)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding the restriction of chemicals used in e-cigarettes (EN4624)
From the Assistant Minister for the Republic regarding a transition into a republic government (EN4626)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding the inclusion of autoimmune conditions under COVID 19 vaccine claims scheme (EN4631)
From the Minister of Social Services to a petition requesting Jobseeker payments for Masters of Teaching students (EN4637)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to legalise, regulate and tax all drugs (EN4642)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding Medicare subsidised psychology sessions (EN4643)
From the Minster for Foreign Affairs to petitions regarding support from Australia to the people of Iran (PN0549, PN0550, EN4572, EN4567, EN4590, EN4632)
In Report No. 7 presented on 20 March 2023—

span.span: in private session in the 47th Parliament on 8 March 2023.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 8 February 2023, 15 February 2023 and 8 March 2023.

p.span: PETITIONS
Presentation

Ms
TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following nine petitions:
Tick-bite Illnesses

Under the DSCATT Clinical Pathway, Australian patients who have not travelled overseas to Lyme disease endemic areas are not allowed to be tested for Lyme Disease (DSCATT Clinical pathway page "v"). Under S. 5.1 it is written that "Lyme Disease is not a notifiable disease in Australia"- and yet just below that at S 5.2 is the sentence "A confirmed case of Lyme disease in Australia requires laboratory evidence AND clinical evidence AND epidemiological evidence." Without Lyme Disease being a notifiable disease, it is impossible for patients to present epidemiological evidence. Ticks can carry many infections. Why deny testing and treatment?

We therefore ask the House to make laws for the following purposes: 1) Australians to be allowed to be tested for any Tick-borne infections by GP's or in hospitals, regardless of where or how the infection was acquired. 2) Australians to be allowed to be treated for any Tick-borne infections for as long or as often as necessary due to the relapsing, remitting nature of some Tick-borne Infections (particularly infections which, if not cured in a timely manner, may develop into chronic illness or trigger new conditions e.g. autoimmune conditions). 3) Statistical record-keeping by the Australian Federal Government for all Tick-borne infections definitively acquired in Australia.
from one citizen (Petition No. PN0556)
National Library of Australia: Trove
It is a very valuable research tool for professional and amateur historians.
We therefore ask the House to legislate for funding for Trove
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4791)
Sponsored Parent (Temporary) Visa

Parent visa processing is out of control. Many applied when processing times were 2 or 3 yrs. It is now 12 yrs & growing. Many will die in the queue and/or not succeed with the application as changes to health increase with age. Research shows grandparents positively influence their grandkids. The processing times have blown out to unreasonable times, robbing Australian children from relationships with their grandparents. The system is broken & breaking more. It needs urgent fixing!
We therefore ask the House to increase the annual places to match the demand & to process the backlog urgently
from 2,627 citizens (Petition No. EN4798)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Vaccinated people are dying or becoming sick at an industrial rate. In order to protect the Australian healthcare system & economy, Australian borders should ideally be closed to all those who are double jabbed (or more), as the second shot seems to be the most deadly one. Entry to Australia will only be allowed under certain conditions:
Tourist—Tourists must obtain health insurance to cover vaccine death & vaccine injuries minimum cover of $30m,
Temporary Visa applicant—same as tourist,
Permanent Resident applicant—No PR approvals should be given unless the PR applicant has a minimum $50m life insurance cover. If the insurance cover ends the PR visa becomes invalid.
No one entering Australia should be covered by Medicare if they were vaccinated for Covid-19 & not already holding PR or citizenship.
We therefore ask the House to
Protect Australian taxpayers & the healthcare Medicare system from collapse due to those who are mRNA vaccinated.

We need an independent investigation to see whether mandatory insurance cover for future tourists, temporary visa holders & permanent resident applicants will be enough to protect the health & Medicare system.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4799)
Housing

The ongoing housing crisis in Australia is a pressing and urgent matter, with thousands of families, single mothers, and the elderly struggling to find affordable housing and forced to live in cars or tents. Landlords are driven by greed to take advantage of the crisis increasing rents by amounts such as $200p/w, with tenants being held hostage to excessive rent increases & no limits in place. As a result rents are at all time high and even those paying taxes with a full time job can not afford a roof over their head. The situation is dire, with 33% of the population experiencing housing insecurity, making it one of the most pressing and urgent issues in the country.
We therefore ask the House to rental increases. Rental increases should be tied to a % increase limit every 12 months. For example 1.5%, interest rate levels or CPI.
2. Implement and incentivize longer-term leases providing housing security and stability for renters.

3. End no-grounds evictions, even for fixed-term agreements. A big problem is at the end of your 6-12 month lease, the landlord can decide to just kick you out of your home resulting in Australians having no housing security.
4. Tax vacant occupied properties higher incentivizing houses to be put on the rental market and discouraging the hoarding of housing.
5. Make social housing more easily accessible.
6. Create public affordable housing that meets the current demand.
7. Address housing affordability.
8. An efficiency commission into government housing services.
from 748 citizens (Petition No. EN4800)
Australian Rail Track Corporation

While the Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) has done good work on the Inland Rail project and others, its status as a statutory corporation means that it is focused on profitability and therefore can result in inferior outcomes for the Australian community. By removing the ARTC's statutory corporation status and bringing it under the direct control of the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts (DITRDCA), the federal government can coordinate better with state governments on rail corridors and not be focused on turning a profit, and therefore bring superior outcomes to the Australian community.
We therefore ask the House to investigate the removal of the ARTC's statutory corporation status and bringing it under the direct control of DITRDCA.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN4802)
Sepsis

Sepsis a life-threatening illness. In 2017-18, more than 20,000 people were treated for sepsis in Queensland hospitals; over 2,000 lost their lives. For adults who survive sepsis, half will be left with a permanent disability or impaired function. It is a leading cause of death and disability in children.

We therefore ask the House to provide routine screening and diagnosis for children at risk patients and those living and working in at risk environment's. At present it's at the jurisdiction of the GP to decide if the patient presents systematic enough to be admitted to hospital for diagnosis. Some infections can take longer than others to become septic such as fungal infections for example.
With a great proportion of people now living in beach towns there is increased risk for people to develop these kinds of infections.
By the time person's are admitted to hospital the damage is already present from the undiagnosed infection which may cause permanent impairment and or disability.
Sepsis occurs when the body's response to an infection causes damage to healthy tissues and organs.

Sepsis can be caused by any type of infection—viral, fungal, or bacterial. It most commonly occurs with bacterial infections of the lungs, urinary tract (bladder, urethra, kidneys), abdomen, skin and soft tissues. It can lead to tissue damage, multiple organ failure and death.
There is no single symptom of sepsis. It can initially look like the flu.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN4805)
Coal Seam Gas Mining
Stop Santos Fracking and endangering The Surat Artesian Basin

We therefore ask the House to stop Santos Gas Fracking and protecting The Surat Artesian Basin from Santos using it to create Hydrogen. Fracking is happening in the US, Canada and of course in our own country of Australia, people are getting sick as a result of the toxic chemicals they are exposed to via both air and water.

The Australian Government need to acknowledge that emissions of polluting chemicals in the air will increase. Pollution brought about by the fracking operation also can also kill crops and pose a severe threat to wildlife. Methane leaks from gas wells and pipelines make fracking a serious contributor to climate change, more serious than CO2. We need to protect the Surat Artesian Basin from Santos. We know that Legislation has been passed in the Australian state of New South Wales (NSW) that allows to feed blends of hydrogen and biomethane into the natural gas pipeline network. That aims to export substantial amounts of green hydrogen to power producers in Japan and wider Asia.

These areas have social, cultural, and economic significance and should never be approached or at risk .Earthquakes, contaminated water, environmental contamination and climate change should not be a part of the world that we hand down to our grandchildren.
"Gamil "means NO
from 117 citizens (Petition No. EN4806)
Diesel

From the perspective of university students. Many are relying on their hard work and exhausting hours to earn enough for just two weeks of living expenses. Some students own diesel SUVs and or even live by themselves, meaning they had to pay taxes on their own despite their mortgage. With diesel being pricy, it turns things more and more unaffordable, and also it inevitably rises the cost of groceries. Research has been done to show that diesel releases less Carbon Dioxide, it has better fuel economy than petrol cars and it has no long term negative effects to the environment.
We therefore ask the House to seriously discuss and lower the cost of diesel so items do not enter extreme inflation.
from 65 citizens (Petition No. EN4807)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 22 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 19 December 2022 to the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP,

Minister for Social Services, regarding petition EN1948 on nationally consistent coercive control laws. As the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General, your email was referred to me for reply.

Coercive control is often a significant part of family and domestic violence, and the Australian Government recognises this as a pressing issue that requires a coordinated, national approach. The Australian Government and State and Te1Titory governments are working together to develop National Principles to Address Coercive Control, which will outline a common understanding of coercive control and its impacts. Once finalised, the National Principles will help raise awareness of coercive control, inform more effective responses to family and domestic violence, and promote more consistent support and safety outcomes for victim-survivors. Public consultation on the draft National Principles was conducted between September to November 2022. The National Principles will now be revised and finalised in 2023, incorporating feedback from the consultation process.

Petition EN1948 calls for legislation to criminalise coercive control in Australia. This is an important issue that is attracting increasing consideration throughout the world and the Government is aware of calls by a range of stakeholders for the creation of a coercive control offence. In Australia, criminalisation is a matter for State and Territory governments as they have primary jurisdiction for this type of offending. New South Wales introduced a standalone offence of coercive control in November 2022, and a number of other jurisdictions are currently considering criminalising this behaviour. The Government supports the States and Territories considering this issue further, and the National Principles will support these considerations.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural enclosing Petition EN3490, with 309 signatures, concerning asylum seekers on Manus and Nauru. I apologise for the delay in responding and your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia is a cohesive, multicultural society of people drawn from a rich variety of cultural backgrounds. The Australian Government knows the important social and economic contribution migrants and refugees have had through our nation's history. The Government is committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs.

While a humane approach to irregular migration is required, we must also ensure that new people smuggling ventures do not reach our shores. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining strong border protection measures, including regional processing, and is upholding the policy setting that individuals who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat will not settle in Australia.

From 1 January 2022, regional processing arrangements are maintained in Nauru only with the former Government ending Australia's regional processing association in PNG on 31 December 2021. The PNG Government independently manages individuals remaining in PNG on a permanent or temporary pathway, including providing ongoing settlement support and services and assistance to pursue other third country migration outcomes.
Transitory persons in Nauru are not detained, are residing and working in the Nauruan community and have ongoing access to a variety of health and welfare services.

I assure you the Government is committed to finding durable migration outcomes for individuals under regional processing, in Nauru and temporarily in Australia, and we continue to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States (US) and New Zealand (NZ). Approximately 1,080 individuals have already resettled in the US and 10 have resettled in NZ, with a sizeable number pursuing this resettlement pathway. The Government is also aware of transitory persons pursuing private sponsorship in Canada and is providing logistical interview and travel assistance to Canada.

Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to achieve permanent migration outcomes and start the next phase of their lives.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3490 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
I am writing to provide a response to petition EN3609, which raises concerns in relation to mobile coverage and Telstra's universal service obligation (USO).

I acknowledge the concern raised about the lack of mobile coverage in parts of the Cabonne Shire and the quality of the copper network. The Australian Government recognises access to reliable and high-quality telecommunications infrastructure is of fundamental impo11ance to Australian households, especially for those in rural and remote communities.

The Universal Service Obligation (USO) is a safeguard focused on the supply of fixed telephone services, while mobile coverage is largely driven by commercial competition, supplemented by targeted funding programs. This has been the approach of governments here and around the world.

Under the USO, Telstra is required to provide fixed voice services to premises in Australia upon reasonable request. Telstra must also maintain existing voice copper connections outside of the NBN fixed line footprint as a pa11 of a contractual copper continuity obligation. This is fu11her supplemented by the Customer Service Guarantee (CSG) and the Network Reliability Framework, which establishes timeframes for connection, repairs and remediation of poorly performing copper voice services.

Telstra is required to report publicly each quarter against a number of key indicators and provides performance details to the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts and the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).

The data reporting requirements include service availability, connection timeframes, faults and outages, repair timeframes and appointment timeframes at the exchange service area level. It also provides national complaint and customer contact handling data.

By ensuring access to more detailed information, this reporting framework provides the community with greater transparency and gives the department a more comprehensive understanding of the performance and reliability of Telstra's network on the ground.
Quarterly reports can be downloaded from Telstra's Regional Service Performance page at www.telstra.com.au/consumer-advice/customer-service/regional-service-performance.

The concerns raised in the petition about the copper network and mobile coverage in the Cabonne Shire have been raised with Telstra. Telstra advises that its records indicate there have not recently been any significant issues with mobile or fixed line services in the Cabonne area, nor were any significant level of faults reported during the time period referenced in the petition. However, Telstra acknowledges that from time to time there may be individual faults on the fixed and/or mobile network.

In relation to the concerns raised about mobile coverage, online maps provided by the national Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) indicate varying levels of 3G and 4G mobile coverage within Cabonne Shire. The local terrain and distance from the nearest mobile base station may also explain why individual areas within Cabonne Shire may experience poor mobile reception.
Telstra has indicated it is planning to build another four mobile base stations around Cabonne Shire, though is unable to advise when these sites are expected to go live.

The Government is making significant investments in regional telecommunications, and this funding will further opportunities to improve mobile coverage in areas such as the Cabonne Shire. The Government's Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia is providing $656 million to improve mobile and broadband connectivity and resilience in rural and regional Australia. This funding includes:
$400 million to boost multi-carrier mobile coverage on highways, and in under-served regional and remote communities, and improve telecommunications resilience;
$200 million for two additional rounds of the RCP to invest in place-based digital connectivity infrastructure projects in regional communities;
$30 million for on-farm connectivity, so farmers can take advantage of connected machinery and sensor technology;
$20 million to conduct an independent audit of mobile coverage to better identify black spots and guide investment priorities; and
$6 million to boost funding for the Regional Tech Hub, which supports regional consumers to access advice and support on digital connectivity options.

The Government recently completed consultation on the draft grant opportunity guidelines for Round 3 of the RCP, which includes opportunities for mobile funding. Applications are expected to open in coming months.

To assist applicants with their submissions, the Government has established a project noticeboard, designed to help communities form partnerships with the telecommunications sector in order to develop applications. More information can be found at www.infrastructure.gov.au/RCP.

The Government is also making significant investments in the National Broadband Network. This includes expanding full-fibre access to a further 1.5 million premises, including over 660,000 premises in regional Australia. The Government has provided $480 million towards upgrading and expanding NBN Co's fixed wireless footprint, which will boost speeds on fixed wireless services and free up capacity on NBN satellite services.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the residents of Cabonne Shire to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Citizenship
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs enclosing Petition EN3934, with 14 signatures, concerning children born in Australia who do not acquire Australian citizenship at birth. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I note the terms of the petition and the request to enable children -born in Australia in 2006 to parents who are neither Australian citizens nor permanent residents to acquire Australian citizenship.

Prior to 20 August 1986, children born in Australia acquired Australian citizenship at birth, regardless of their parent(s) visa or citizenship status. The legislation was subsequently amended so that children born on or after 20 August 1986, who did not acquire Australian citizenship at birth, automatically acquire Australian citizenship if they have been ordinarily resident in Australia for ten years from birth.

Therefore, a child born in Australia in 2006 to parents who are neither Australian citizens nor permanent residents may still acquire Australian citizenship by operation of law on their 10th birthday, provided they have been ordinarily resident in Australia throughout the ten years from birth. In such cases, the child can apply for evidence of citizenship with the Department of Home Affairs to obtain proof of their Australian citizenship at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/citizenship/certificate/get-a-certificate.
Information on other pathways to become an Australian citizen is also available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/citizenship/become-a-citizen.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3934 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Telecommunications
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter of 28 November 2022, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN4495.

I acknowledge community concern about the amount of time young people are spending online. However, many children, especially older children, have legitimate reasons to have a mobile phone. The view of the Australian Government is that banning mobile phone ownership for those under 18 would not be a proportionate response.
Instead, the Government has invested in assisting parents, carers and children to stay safe online and to make informed decisions about the time they are spending online.

The Government believes that parents and carers are best placed to make decisions about their children's use of technology. Accordingly, the Government focusses on empowering parents and carers to make educated and informed decisions. The eSafety Commissioner maintains a range of supportive resources about balancing time online and managing digital media. These resources inform parents and young people about the impacts of spending time online and provide advice such as how to recognise online addiction and how to create healthy boundaries with technology.

eSafety has up-to-date information about parental controls and software tools that allow parents to monitor and limit what their children do or see online and set time limits on devices. Free online webinars, downloadable books, information sheets and resources with easy to follow advice can be found at www.esafety.gov.au/parents.

The Government has also delivered on its election commitment to provide $6 million over three years for the national rollout of eSmart digital and media literacy products, developed by the Alannah & Madeline Foundation. These programs build the digital skills young people need to stay safe and thrive online, and include modules specific to self-regulation and managing time online. More information about the eSmart products can be found at www.alannahandmadeline.org.au/what-we-do/prevention-programs/esmart.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this response is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Gymnastics Australia
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter dated 28 November 2022, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN4498).

I note this petition refers to the progress of Gymnastics Australia joining the National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse (the Scheme) and asks the Australian Government to withdraw its funding to Gymnastics Australia if it has not joined the Scheme by December 2022.

I have been advised by the Scheme that Gymnastics Australia has worked constructively with officials throughout the joining process within the required timeframes. This process includes an assessment of whether Gymnastics Australia is able to meet the legislative requirements of the Scheme in order to join, covering aspects such as estimated redress liability and financial surety.

I acknowledge that onboarding gymnastics institutions named in applications to the Scheme is taking time to progress. This is because the Scheme is working closely with gymnastics institutions and the relevant state and national sporting organisations in this sport to explore all available options for their participation in the Scheme, so that outcomes can be achieved for survivors of institutional child sexual abuse.

The Government considers that where an institution is named in an application to the Scheme and can participate in the Scheme, it should do so. If an institution named in an application does not work cooperatively to join the Scheme, this is taken seriously and consequences may be applied.

Consequences applied to institutions within the scope of the Scheme that fail to join may be publicly named by the Scheme Operator, have their basic charitable status removed, and become ineligible for future Commonwealth and State grant funding.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Family Law
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 28 November 2022 regarding Petition No EN4506, presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions. The petition requests the creation of a register and the imposition of a fine for those who are proven to have provided false allegations in court. As Attorney-General, the federal law system, including family law, falls within my portfolio responsibilities.
The Australian Government does not agree with the creation of a register as suggested in the petition.

The Australian Government is committed to improving the family law system so that it is accessible, safer, simpler to use, and delivers justice and fairness for all Australian families. An exposure draft of the Family Law Amendment Bill 2023 has recently been released. The proposed reforms are aimed at simplifying legislation and ensuring that the best interests of children are prioritised and placed at the centre of the family law system. More information about the draft reforms are available on the Attorney-General's Department website at https://consultations.ag.gov.au/families-and-marriage/family-law-amendment-bill/
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Australian Democracy
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence about petition EN4539 about trends in federal election voter turnout. As electoral matters fall within my responsibilities as Special Minister of State, I am pleased to respond.

The Labor Party has led legislation for federal electoral reform in Australia. Reforms by the Hawke Government in the 1980s provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and our democracy. Importantly, that Government also transformed our democratic institutions with the creation of the independent Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) to conduct and oversee elections.

All Australian citizens aged 18 years and over have the right and responsibility to participate in our democracy by voting in federal elections and referenda. The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) confirms while the turnout rate has declined since the 1990s, the number of electors voting has increased substantially election after election. More critically, turnout as a proportion of the total eligible population has been trending upwards since 2010.

The AEC considers the current apparent decline in the turnout rate is in part a product of very high rates of enrolment, and in particular the Federal Direct and Enrolment Update (FDEU). Introduced by the Gillard Labor Government, the FDEU facilitates enfranchisement of all Australians. The program enables the AEC to access reliable information to add unenrolled individuals to the roll and update information for those already enrolled. As the program automates enrolment of electors, in some instances it will identify eligible electors who are less engaged with the electoral process or are disinclined to vote (these individuals will be counted as enrolled individuals but may not vote).

It is also worth noting the COVID-19 pandemic effected the turnout for the 2022 election. While the secure telephone voting service allowed over 75,000 COVID-positive voters to cast their ballot in 2022, the AEC considers some electors were reticent to vote in person despite controls in place.

As the petition notes, the AEC offers a range of voting options, advertises extensively in multiple languages and was very active in social media for the 2022 federal election. The AEC uses active public awareness, education and advertising to support voters to understand the importance of voting, particularly in the lead up to electoral events. The AEC's National Electoral Education Centre provides an educational experience to engage and inform visitors about democracy and how to vote, and has approximately 95,000 visitors per year.

In addition, the AEC undertakes targeted engagement and education with a range of elector cohorts who have historically experienced barriers to enrolment and voting, for example through the Indigenous Electoral Participation Program. The AEC remains committed to increasing the delivery of the voting franchise to all eligible electors. It is therefore continuously looking at ways to improve enrolment, turnout, and formality.

In response to the direct request of the petitioners, for the House to investigate this issue, in August last year I wrote to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to initiate inquiry into the 2022 Federal Election. The Committee conducts inquiries into such matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration and includes members from both houses and across the political spectrum. Information about the Committee is available here: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters—Parliament of Australia (aph.gov.au).

As part of the Committee's inquiry into the 2022 Election, I have asked it consider ways to encourage increased electoral participation and support enfranchisement generally, and this is reflected in its terms of reference. The Government looks forward to the findings and recommendations of the Committee. As the Special Minister of State responsible for electoral matters, I will be committed to pursuing support for measures proposed by the Committee that will deliver increased access to enfranchisement for Australians.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Farrell
Assange, Mr Julian Paul
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN4577 to me on extraditing Julian Assange back to his home country.

I understand there is strong interest in Mr Assange's case and a depth of community sentiment. The Australian Government has been clear in its view that Mr Assange's case has dragged on for long enough and that it should be brought to a close. I have personally expressed this view to the governments of the United Kingdom and United States.

As we do for other Australians facing legal proceedings overseas, the Australian Government is following Mr Assange's case closely and offering consular assistance to him. The Australian Government is unable to intervene in another country's legal or court processes, just as they are unable to intervene in Australia's.

While we are doing what we can between the Australian Government and other governments concerned, there are limits until Mr Assange has concluded the legal processes. In a comparable case the resolution by government was only possible once the legal processes had been concluded. I will continue to raise this matter at appropriate levels.
Thank you for taking the time to present this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong
Disability Services
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence dated 6 February 2023, concerning petition number EN4583. The petition requests a reform of the regulation of disabled parking across Australia, making it a requirement for all public places to include a number of disability parking spaces for wheelchair users and for ambulatory people with disability.
The Australian Government aims to ensure that people with disability live in accessible and well-designed communities with opportunity for full inclusion in all aspects of life.
Use of accessible car parking spaces is determined by the Australian Disability Parking Scheme (the Scheme), including the Australian Disability Parking Permit. National eligibility criteria are:
the person is unable to walk and always requires the use of a wheelchair;
the ability to walk is severely restricted by a permanent medical condition or disability; or
the ability to walk is severely restricted by a temporary medical condition or disability.
As state and territories are responsible for administration around the Scheme, all enquiries about the Scheme should be directed to the relevant state or territory authority.

The Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (DDA) is in place to eliminate discrimination against people with disability as far as possible, and to promote community acceptance of the principle that people with disability have the same fundamental rights as all members of the community.

The DDA provides that direct and indirect discrimination on the basis of disability is unlawful in a broad range of areas of public life, including access to premises and access to goods, services and facilities.

The DDA is supplemented by a series of Disability Standards and Guidelines, providing more detail on rights and responsibilities about equal access and opportunity for people with disability. This includes the Disability (Access to Premises—Buildings) Standards 2010 (Premises Standards).

The Premises Standards aim to provide people with disability with dignified and equitable access to public buildings. These Standards came into effect on 1 May 2011, and apply to building work after this date.

Where car parking is provided in or around a building, and the car park is associated with that building, the Premises Standards require that accessible car parking spaces must be provided (other than in relation to Class 2 apartment buildings). These spaces are required to be larger than a conventional space to facilitate a person transferring from a vehicle to their wheelchair or other mobility aid or disembarking in their wheelchair.

The Premises Standards also provide details of the number of accessible car parking spaces required in a car park depending on the classification of the building and based on the ratio to the total number of car parking spaces provided. There is nothing to prevent a developer or manager from providing a greater ratio than that required should they wish to do so.

The Minister for Industry and Science, in consultation with the Attorney-General, is required to review the effectiveness of the Premises Standards in achieving their objects every 5 years. During the most recent review in 2021, participants indicated that the availability of accessible car parking spaces remains a barrier to accessing public buildings.

Issues around the size and location of accessible car parking spaces were also indicated, noting that many stakeholders suggested that accessible parking is not 'one size fits all'. As a result, the 2021 review has recommended the Australian Government lead a regulatory impact analysis on whether current accessible car parking ratios in the Premises Standards are adequate.
It is expected this work will be completed before the next review in 2026.
Further information about the Premises Standards and 2021 review can be found at www.industry.gov.au.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence dated 6 February 2023, concerning Petition EN4584 on introducing a Universal Basic Income.

Australia has a well-targeted, means-tested social security system that provides financial assistance to those most in need, while encouraging self-provision whenever possible. The foundation of the Australian system is a safety net of payments to individuals, ensuring access to a minimum standard of living.
This is achieved through:
flat-rate payments with maximum rates of assistance set relative to need, not income replacement or maintenance;
targeted assistance that is needs-based, with income and assets tests operating so individuals with the fewest means get the highest amount of support;
assistance that is not time-limited and is provided for as long as it is needed; and
payments that are financed from general government revenue, and not based on past contributions from individuals.

Australia's social security system is recognised internationally by organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development for its targeted nature, which significantly contributes to its sustainability.

A universal payment for all Australians would result in taxpayer-funded support being provided to people who may have considerable private means. Targeting ensures the Government is able to meet other important budgetary objectives, such as spending on health and education.

The additional costs from a universal basic income would far exceed the Services Australia savings from not administering the social security means test. Such a scheme would impact on the Government's ability to maintain a fiscally sustainable safety net for individuals in need in the future.
The Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Jammu and Kashmir
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4592, concerning the situation in Jammu and Kashmir.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to advancing human rights globally through our bilateral relationships and engagement in multilateral forums. Australia regularly discusses human rights matters with our Indian counterparts. The Indian Government understands Australia's principled position to promote, protect and respect human rights, as well as our enduring expectation that all countries uphold the fundamental rights of their citizens.

Australia encourages the peaceful settlement of the final status of Jammu and Kashmir, underscored by the protection of human rights. Ultimately, the Kashmir dispute is a bilateral matter for India and Pakistan to resolve peacefully through dialogue.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair
Thank you for the notice of a petition referral (petition number EN4606) dated 6 February 2023, concerning the social security partner income test.

Australia's social security system is designed to provide a safety net for people who, for reasons such as age, disability, caring responsibilities or unemployment, are unable to fully support themselves. The Australian Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.

The social security income test uses the gross income of both partners, even if one of the partners does not receive a social security payment. This is based on the principle that couples are able to pool their resources for their mutual benefit. Couples generally share their expenses, such as various utilities including electricity, gas, internet and water. Accordingly, the income of each member of a couple is assessed for the purposes of the social security income test.

Taking into account the combined gross income and assets of both partners also ensures that partnered couples with similar (combined) levels of resources receive similar support from the social security system. If a partnered person's income support entitlements were based solely on their own income, this would result in unfair outcomes. For example, a couple where one person earned $80,000 and the other earned no income would receive more income support than another couple who both earned $40,000. In a needs-based social security system, this would not be equitable.

If a partnered person's income support entitlements were based solely on their own income, it would also create the situation where some couples could arrange their affairs so that only one member of a couple earns income—for example, income from investments—with the other member of the couple able to obtain a higher level of support from the social security system than would otherwise be the case.

Services Australia (Centrelink) has social workers who can assist people who are struggling financially. They can provide information or a referral to financial counselling services which are free. The Department of Social Services also provides funding to community organisations to deliver free, voluntary and confidential financial counselling services. Under these services, financial counsellors work with people in financial difficulty to address their financial problems, manage debt and make informed choices about their money in the future.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Human Rights: Eritrea and Tigray
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email regarding petition EN4617 on the conflict in Tigray, northern Ethiopia.

The Australian Government welcomed the 2 November 2022 peace agreement between the Ethiopian Government and the Tigray People's Liberation Front. We have been closely monitoring its implementation, and continue to encourage all parties to seize this opportunity to build an enduring peace in Ethiopia.

During his visit to Ethiopia in February, the Assistant Minister for Foreign Affairs, Hon Tim Watts MP, discussed progress on the peace agreement, and the urgent need for a country-wide transitional justice framework, with Ethiopia's State Minister for Foreign Affairs, H.E. Ambassador Mesganu Arga Moach.

The withdrawal of Eritrean military forces from Ethiopian territory is vital to the success of the peace agreement. Australia has regularly called on Eritrea to cease its involvement in the conflict and has voiced deep concerns over the egregious human rights abuses perpetrated by Eritrean forces, including murder, the forced return of Eritrean refugees, rape and other sexual and gender-based violence. We also continue to raise our concerns about the human rights situation inside Eritrea, including through multilateral fora such as the United Nations Human Rights Council.

The Australian Government welcomes recent United Nations reporting of gradual improvements to humanitarian access in Tigray but recognises the humanitarian situation remains dire. Since September 2022, Australia has committed $25 million in funding to help address food insecurity in Ethiopia and other Horn of Africa countries. This is in addition to the $232 million Australia has provided to the World Food Programme to respond to global food insecurity since July 2021. We continue to call for all sides to facilitate humanitarian access across northern Ethiopia.
I thank the Petitions Committee for highlighting the situation facing the people in northern Ethiopia.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong
Human Rights: Eritrea and Tigray
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email regarding petition EN4619 on Eritrea's involvement in the conflict in Tigray, northern Ethiopia.

The Australian Government welcomed the 2 November 2022 peace agreement between the Ethiopian Government and the Tigray People's Liberation Front. We have been closely monitoring its implementation. On 17 February 2023, during his visit to Ethiopia, the Assistant Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon Tim Watts MP, raised the implementation of the peace agreement and the need for a country-wide transitional justice framework with Ethiopia's State Minister for Foreign Affairs, H.E. Ambassador Mesganu Arga Moach.

Australia recognises the withdrawal of Eritrean forces from Ethiopian territory is vital to the success of the peace agreement and we have consistently called on Eritrea to cease its involvement in the conflict. We will continue to encourage all parties to seize this opportunity to build an enduring peace in Ethiopia.

The Australian Government co-sponsored the United Nations Human Rights Council (HRC) resolution of 17 December 2021 which established a Commission of Human Rights Experts on Ethiopia to investigate, collect evidence and provide support to Ethiopia on accountability and transitional justice. We also co-sponsored the renewal of the Commission's mandate in October 2022 for a further 12 months. Australia will continue to call for comprehensive human rights investigations, justice and accountability.

We have regularly raised concerns over the Eritrean government's human rights record, including in multilateral fora. During the HRC's Interactive Dialogue on the Oral Update by the Special Rapporteur on Eritrea on 4 March 2022, we expressed our concerns at prolonged national service; forced and child labour; restrictions on freedom of association, expression, and belief; and serious human rights violations by Eritrean troops in Ethiopia, including the forced return of Eritrean refugees. This followed statements on Eritrea by the Australian Government in HRC sessions in February and July 2021, June 2020, and during Eritrea's last Human Rights Universal Periodic Review in January 2019.

Australia welcomes recent United Nations reporting of gradual improvements to humanitarian access in Tigray but recognises the situation remains dire. We continue to call on all parties to the conflict to facilitate safe access by humanitarian agencies to reach those in need of food, health and other essential goods and services.

The petition requests Australia consider an intake of Eritrean refugees from northern Ethiopia. Australia's Humanitarian Program intake draws from a range of nationalities, ethnic and religious groups, reflecting the displacement arising from conflict and persecution in many areas of the world. The Program operates flexibly to respond to evolving humanitarian situations and global resettlement needs. It seeks to balance responses to emergency situations, while providing places for other caseloads in need of resettlement across the world, in line with advice from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR}. A total of 13,750 places in 2022-23 will ensure we can provide permanent resettlement to those most in need, and provide appropriate support for the travel and resettlement of refugees and others requiring Australia's protection.

Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. This, of course, includes those affected by the conflict in northern Ethiopia. Each application is considered on its individual merit.
Priority is given to the most vulnerable applicants who are assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and those proposed by an immediate family member.
I thank the Petitions Committee for highlighting the situation facing the people in Eritrea and northern Ethiopia.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong
Nicotine Vaping Products
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding Petition EN4624 asking the House to ban the use of harmful chemicals (including, but not limited to, flavourants such as diacetyl, nicotine, heavy metals and ultra-fine particles) in vapes.
The Australian Government recognises that nicotine vaping products (NVPs) are known to pose certain health risks and that the long-term health consequences of vaping are still uncertain.
The Government is also concerned about the increasing use of NVPs by young people and the evidence that vaping can lead to the uptake of cigarette smoking.

Current laws limit the allowable concentration of nicotine and prohibit certain ingredients in NVPs (see section 7 and Schedule 1 of the Therapeutic Goods (Standard for Nicotine Vaping Products) (TGO 110} Order 2021 available at www.legislation.gov.au/Details/F2021L00595. The current list of prohibited ingredients includes five flavouring agents, including diacetyl, and other hazardous substances.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) recently undertook a significant public consultation process on potential reforms to the regulation of NVPs in Australia. The aim was to seek feedback on actions the Government could take to better prevent children and adolescents from accessing NVPs, while supporting access to products of known composition and quality for smoking cessation with a doctor's prescription. The consultation paper sought views on amending the quality and safety standards for NVPs, including potential reduction in the allowable concentration of nicotine, and prohibition of or restrictions on flavouring, colouring and cooling ingredients.

The consultation closed on 16 January 2023 and almost 4,000 submissions were received. The responses are currently being considered by the Government before decisions are made on any changes to the regulatory framework for NVPs.

Vaping products that do not contain nicotine are not generally 'therapeutic goods' and are generally not subject to the requirements of TGO 110. However, the TGA is currently considering whether it is possible to amend the Poisons Standard to effectively restrict the inclusion of the TGO 110 prohibited ingredients in vaping products that do not contain nicotine.

In the Poisons Standard, medicines and chemicals are classified into Schedules according to the level of regulatory control over the availability of the medicine or chemical required to protect public health and safety. The limitations in the Poisons Standard are then given legal effect through state and territory legislation.

The prohibited ingredients specified in TGO 110 are not currently included in the Poisons Standard. However, listing of these chemicals in the Poisons Standard could potentially prevent them being included in non-nicotine vaping products.

More generally, the Department of Health and Aged Care, including the TGA, is working with other Commonwealth agencies and the states and territories to develop a coordinated and broad-ranging programme to address issues relating to vaping.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023, on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4626, regarding a transition into a Republic government.
The Albanese Labor Government believes that our nation's Constitution is a living document which should be amended to reflect contemporary Australia and to embody Australian values.

Over twenty years have passed since the Australian people were consulted about our Constitution. While there's been no referendum since 1999, there's been no successful referendum since 1977. Indeed, it's been the longest period we have gone without the government consulting Australians about updating Constitution.

The Albanese Government's priority for Constitutional reform remains recognition of First Nations peoples in the Australian Constitution, including an enshrined Voice to Parliament, as outlined in the Uluru Statement from the Heart.

The Government supports and will work towards establishing an Australian Republic with an Australian head of state. Each and every Australian, no matter their background, birthplace, gender or religion should be able to aspire to be our nation's head of state.

The Albanese Government will continue to consult the Australian people, including on potential models for an Australian Republic. While I have been appointed Assistant Minister for the Republic to advance the debate on an Australian head of state, Constitutional recognition and a Voice to Parliament for First Nations people remain the Government's Constitutional reform priority.
Thank you for bringing petition EN4626 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for the Republic, Mr Thistlethwaite
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding petition EN4631 that seeks to include autoimmune conditions as eligible conditions under the COVID-19 Vaccine Claims Scheme (Scheme).

The Australian Government has in place a no-fault compensation scheme, in the form of the Scheme, which acknowledges that in certain circumstances, there are certain Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) recognised reactions that vaccine recipients might have to a TGA approved COVID-19 vaccine.

The Scheme is designed to ensure that people who have suffered a moderate to significant adverse effect recognised by the TGA, as a direct result of receiving COVID-19 vaccine, have faster access to compensation through a no-fault process that avoids the need for litigation in a court.
To be eligible under the Scheme, the COVID-19 vaccine recipient must meet the following requirements:
suffered a clinical condition or administration related injury most likely as a result of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine
received inpatient hospital treatment (with limited exceptions) and
met the threshold for accessing the Scheme of at least $1,000 in losses (such as out-of-pocket medical costs and lost income).
The following table specifies the moderate to significant harm covered by the Scheme:

span.span: Vaccine{s) from which the clinical condition results

p.span: Anaphylactic reaction
AstraZeneca Pty Limited
Pfizer Australia Pty Limited
Moderna Australia Pty Limited
Novavax Inc.
Thrombosis with Thrombocytopenia Syndrome
AstraZeneca Pty Limited
Myocarditis
Pfizer Australia Pty Limited
Moderna Australia Pty Limited
Pericarditis
Pfizer Australia Pty Limited
Moderna Australia Pty Limited
Capillary leak syndrome
AstraZeneca Pty Limited
Demyelinating disorders including Guillain Barre Syndrome (GBS)
AstraZeneca Pty Limited
Thrombocytopenia, including immune Thrombocytopenia, identified as a final diagnosis
AstraZeneca Pty Limited

Administration Related Injuries which are a clinically diagnosed: shoulder injury; or other moderate to significant physical injury giving rise to permanent impairment or the need for an extended period of medical treatment but excluding the injuries in Table 2.
Any TGA approved COVID-19 Vaccine

span.span: Table 2—Harm NOT covered by the Scheme

p.span: COVID-19
psychological and psychiatric conditions (e.g. shock)
secondary injuries (e.g. injury suffered when fainting, or a haematoma at the injection site that becomes infected) and

the following other injuries unless they form part of the symptom complex of a clinical condition listed in Table 1: headache; fatigue; injection site reaction; muscle or joint pain; dizziness; diarrhoea; pain in extremity; fever; insomnia; nausea; vomiting; lethargy; hyperhidrosis; chills; decreased appetite; malaise; lymphadenopathy; somnolence; abdominal pain; puritus; urticaria/rash; influenza- like illness; angioedema; anxiety-related reactions such as hyperventilation and fainting.

Autoimmune diseases such as diabetes are not currently included in the Scheme. For a new clinical condition to be added to the Scheme, the clinical condition must be added to the Product Information for the specific COVID-19 vaccine and verified by the TGA as a serious clinical condition to be covered under the Scheme.

The TGA closely monitors the safety of COVID-19 vaccines and has a well-established and robust system in place to capture reports of suspected adverse effects of all medicines including the COVID-19 vaccines. The TGA receives reports of adverse reactions from consumers, health professionals, pharmaceutical companies, and state and territory health departments.

The petition also commented on the claims process. As part of the claims process the patient will need to submit evidence demonstrating the clinical condition or injury suffered. All claims need to be supported with a medical report from their treating doctor or hospital physician with the treating doctor's opinion on the diagnosed condition or injury and likely link to vaccination. This medical report will also include information about the healthcare needs, the duration of the hospitalisation and any ongoing medical care requirements.

Evidence of losses claimed, such as lost earning and out-of-pocket medical costs will also need to be provided. This will enable the decision maker to be satisfied that the claim is for a clinical condition or injury covered by the Scheme and that the treating doctor confirms that the vaccination is the most likely cause.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2023, concerning petition number EN4637, which proposes access to JobSeeker Payment for students undertaking a Master of Teaching qualification.

The JobSeeker Payment is designed to support people who are looking for work, with incentive structures built in to support this. It is an income support payment that provides financial assistance to people aged 22 years to Age Pension age, who have capacity to work now or in the near future, meet the eligibility rules, income and assets tests and, unless temporarily exempted, meet mutual obligations.

JobSeeker recipients are able to undertake approved study to contribute to their mutual obligation requirements provided that the study meets certain criteria. The course must be less than one year in duration, be likely to lead to an employment outcome for the jobseeker by bridging a skills gap and be in an identified area of skills shortage and high labour demand. JobSeeker Payment recipients who are Workforce Australia Online participants are limited to studying specified approved courses listed on myskills.gov.au, which are either funded by JobTrainer or subsidised by a state or territory government.

Most JobSeeker Payment recipients must actively look for work, participate in activities that increase the likelihood of their finding work and be prepared to accept any offer of suitable employment. These conditions are in line with Section 613 of the Social Security Act I99I.

Student payments such as Austudy are designed for students who are undertaking an approved course of full-time study (generally 75 per cent or more of a full-time study load) at an approved educational institution. An approved course of study is a course that the Minister for Social Services has determined under section 5D of the Student Assistance Act 1973 to be a secondary, tertiary or approved masters course for the purposes of that Act.

Student payment rates depend on the recipient's individual circumstances such as whether they are partnered or have dependent children. For further information on payment rates and eligibility, please refer to the Guide to Australian Government payments at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/guide-to-australian-government-payments.

Incentives are provided to allow those receiving a student payment to earn more income without automatically losing their entitlement and concessions. The higher personal income threshold and income bank for students encourages them to supplement their student payments through paid employment. Under the personal income free area threshold, a student can earn up to $480 a fortnight before their Austudy starts to be affected.

The student income bank allows students to accumulate any unused portion of their fortnightly income free area up to $12,000. Students can use the amount in their student income bank to offset any income above the threshold. The student income bank provides additional flexibility for students to take advantage of seasonal employment during semester breaks when their study load is reduced.
In contrast, recipients of JobSeeker payment have a personal income threshold of $150 a fortnight and have access to working credit to offset income above this threshold.

Where recipients of income support payments have additional costs, such as those associated with renting in the private market and raising children, other payments such as the Commonwealth Rent Assistance and Family Tax Benefit are available. Other supplementary benefits that may
be payable depending on circumstances include Pharmaceutical Allowance, Carer Allowance, Remote Area Allowance, Telephone Allowance and Mobility Allowance, as well as a concession card.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Illicit Drugs
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4642 regarding illicit drug issues in Australia.

The Australian Government does not plan to legalise the use of illicit drugs at the national level. Harms from the use of illicit drugs impact on individuals, families and communities through negative health, legal, social and economic outcomes. More broadly, alcohol, tobacco and other drug problems are associated with social determinants, such as discrimination, unemployment, homelessness, poverty and family breakdown.
I would like to assure you the Government is committed to preventing and minimising the harms associated with the use of illicit drugs on individuals, families, and communities.

The approach to achieving this is set out in the overarching framework of the National Drug Strategy 2017-2026 (Strategy). The Strategy recognises Australia's long-standing and ongoing commitment to a balanced approach between health and law enforcement, and outlines a national commitment to harm minimisation through the adoption of evidence-based demand, supply and harm reduction strategies.

Under the Drug and Alcohol Program the Government is providing more than $870 million over four years (from 1 July 2022) to support drug and alcohol treatment services and prevention, research and communication activities. This includes investing more than $710 million for drug and alcohol treatment services over these four years.

Australia is a signatory of all three United Nations international drug control conventions. The conventions provide flexibility to allow for the implementation of a wide variety of national and sub-national harm reduction initiatives.

I note that a number of the matters raised in the Petition are not within my remit as the Minister for Health and Aged Care, including taxation and the release of prisoners convicted of non-violent drug crimes. It is also important to note issues relating to the legalisation and decriminalisation of illicit drugs are largely matters for state and territory governments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Medicare: Mental Health
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding petition number EN4643 on the additional 10 sessions introduced under the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) Better Access initiative in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Australian Government's decision to allow the temporary Better Access expansion to cease as planned on 31 December 2022 was informed by an independent evaluation undertaken by the University of Melbourne. The final Better Access evaluation report can be viewed at www.health.gov.au/resources/collections/evaluation-of-the-better-access-initiative-final-report.

The evaluation found that while people using Better Access experienced positive outcomes, those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, regional, rural and remote areas as well as aged care residents are missing out. It also found the group most likely to benefit from additional sessions were those with complex mental health needs, but the sessions were not targeted towards this cohort. These findings greatly concern the Government.

Consequently, Better Access needs to be reformed. On 30 January 2023, the Assistant Minister for Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, the Hon Emma McBride MP and I convened a forum with approximately 80 experts, clinicians, service providers and people with lived experience to discuss how to develop and implement a more equitable Better Access program and broader mental health system—one based on the evidence—that ensures no one is left behind.

Discussions at the forum highlighted the deep structural challenges currently faced by the health and mental health system can only be properly addressed in ongoing partnership with the mental health sector. To this end, the Government recently announced $8.5 million to support lived experience engagement and establish a regular mental health stakeholder forum to increase transparency and accountability in mental health reform. This will help ensure any changes to our system are well-considered, robust and sustainable. I look forward to engaging with the sector in this capacity.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Human Rights: Iran
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petitions EN0549, EN0550, EN4572; EN4567, EN4590 and EN4632 requesting the Australian Government to support the people of Iran and take stronger action against the Iranian regime.
We have all been moved by the bravery of the Iranian people and appalled by the brutality of the Iranian regime towards its own citizens.

Australia has been integral to building pressure internationally and was at the forefront of efforts to remove Iran from the Commission for the Status of Women. Australia co- sponsored and advocated for the successful Human Rights Council resolution for the establishment of an independent fact-finding mission to investigate human rights violations in Iran.

The Albanese Government has imposed Magnitsky-style human rights sanctions on 22 individuals and three entities over their involvement in the Iranian regime's abhorrent, flagrant, and continued human rights violations. Among those subject to Magnitsky-style human rights sanctions are Iran's Morality Police and the Basij Resistance Force, and senior law enforcement and military figures—including those within the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC}.

Additionally, Australia has joined partners to impose additional targeted financial sanctions on seven Iranian individuals and five entities involved in the production and supply of drones to Russia, that have been used in its illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine.

The Australian Government has consistently and forcefully raised our concerns directly with Iran. I have written to Iran's Foreign Minister and the Attorney-General has written to his counterpart, including to reaffirm in the strong terms Australia's opposition to the death penalty. We have summoned Iran's representative in Canberra on numerous occasions. Our Ambassador has made representations in Tehran, including directly to the Deputy Foreign Minister.

I understand the calls for listing the IRGC as a terrorist organisation. The actions of the IRGC are unconscionable. They must be held to account. The purpose of listings under the criminal code is to make it easier to prosecute individuals in Australia for supporting terrorist organisations. It is not a foreign policy tool to increase pressure on foreign governments. The Australian Government is focused on taking meaningful steps to put pressure on the IRGC. That is why I have sanctioned 12 IRGC-linked individuals and seven IRGC-linked entities. These designations build on Australia's targeted sanctions on the IRGC as a whole, which Australia has had in place since 2010.
I acknowledge the requests to expel Iranian diplomats. Embassies and diplomatic staff are essential to the maintenance of channels of communication between governments.

Australia has maintained an uninterrupted diplomatic presence in Iran since our Embassy opened in Tehran in 1968—through a revolution, a near decade-long war and very difficult periods when other like-minded countries have left. It has never been an endorsement of the regime; it is a channel to protect our interests and our people.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned by reports of families and protestors being harassed and intimidated. The Department of Home Affairs' Counter Foreign Interference Coordination Centre is working with the community to conduct targeted engagement of foreign interference. The Australian Government urges families and individuals who may have received threats to report them to the Australian Federal Police or their state police service.

The Albanese Government has taken stronger action against Iran on human rights than any previous Australian government. We will continue to deliberately and strategically put pressure on the Iranian regime to uphold human rights.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong (Petition Nos PN0549, PN0550, EN4572, EN4567, EN4590 and EN4632)
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): The referral of petitions to ministers is a valuable part of the petitioning process. Most petitions presented to the House are referred to the minister responsible for the matters raised in the petition for a written response. Under the standing orders, ministers are expected to provide a response within 90 days of the petition's presentation.

For some petitions, it can be difficult to determine which minister is best placed to provide a response. For others, the issues raised can relate to more than one portfolio area. For these reasons, there can be some back and forth between the secretariat and departments throughout the referral process.

Unfortunately, the Petitions Committee was recently made aware that a petition had not received a response because it had been referred to the wrong minister. On behalf of the committee, I'd like to apologise to the petitioners for the delay. I note that the petition has now been referred to the correct minister and I look forward to presenting a response in due course.

The committee has taken this as an opportunity to review its procedures for the referral of petitions to ministers, particularly in cases where a petition could potentially be referred to more than one minister. When referring a petition, the committee will now ask the minister to advise the committee if a petition should be redirected. The committee will also track the transfer of petitions between ministers more closely.
The committee will continue to work to ensure that Australian citizens and residents who petition the House receive a thoughtful response within a reasonable timeframe.

I'd like to highlight the role that really key petitions have played in the history of Australia. One of those was in this parliament just last week: a copy and some of the original of the Larrakia petition. It was here as part of a showcase of our national collecting institutions. The Larrakia petition begins this way:
The British settlers took our land. No treaties were signed with the tribes.
It goes on to contrast that with:
The British Crown signed treaties with the Maoris in New Zealand and the Indians in North America.

This petition was an appeal to the Queen for help. It was created by the Larrakia people in 1972. They are the traditional owners of the Darwin region in the Northern Territory. At the time of the petition, they were fighting for their ownership of a stretch of coastal land near Darwin to be acknowledged.

As I said, the Larrakia people addressed this petition to Queen Elizabeth II. To create it, they organised for papers to be circulated to Aboriginal communities across mainland Australia. In these communities, supporters of the petition signed the paper with either their signature or a thumbprint. Over a thousand signatures and thumbprints were collected. The papers were then returned to Darwin, where the finished petition was pasted together in a more-than-three-metre-long scroll.

In 1972, when there was a royal visit to Darwin planned by Princess Margaret, Queen Elizabeth's sister, the Larrakia people camped outside Government House, where she was staying, in the hope that they could present the petition. Unfortunately, that didn't happen, and the Larrakia people then patched the petition, which had become torn during that process, with sticky tape, and they mailed it to Buckingham Palace. When Buckingham Palace received the petition, they forwarded it to the Australian government via the Governor-General. It was placed on file in the Department of Aboriginal affairs in 1972, and that's how it became part of the collection of the National Archives. And the National Archives, as I say, brought a facsimile of that petition to the parliament last week, and I know many in this chamber visited the national collection showcase and saw it. They also brought some of the original pages with them.

The Larrakia petition is one of the most significant documents created by First Nations activists in the 1970s. The calls for change made by the petition, including land rights, treaty and political representation, clearly continue to have significance for all of us today.

The other very significant petition that originated in the Northern Territory is the Yirrkala bark petitions, which now the National Museum of Australia holds, and I believe parts of it are displayed in this place. In August 1963, two bark petitions were presented to the parliament, to the House of Representatives. It was the Yolngu's first formal attempt to have their land rights recognised.
